IMAGERIE

MODERNE

Le propre de l'esprit artiste est d'être à la remorque d’une mode. Incapable de découvrir

des trésors, il est prêt à admirer ce que d’autres aiment à condition que le temps ou la valeur
marchande donne une pseudo consécration à des objets souvent admirables. Tel qui méprisait voici quelques dizaines d'années les charmantes images d'Epinal en fait aujourd'hui
collection, car ce sont les manifestations populaires qui pâtissent le plus de ces vogues

soudaines.
Méprisées aujourd’hui on recherchera demain les extraordinaires couvertures des suppléments illustrés du Petit Journal et du Petit Parisien qui donnent à l’actualité et à l’histoire
un commentaire si parfaitement expressif. L'Œil de la Police était une de ces galeries comparables aux panoramas qui émerveillaient nos jeunes yeux dans les fêtes de jadis, au Trône
ou à Neuilly.
Je voudrais aujourd’hui, avant que le snobisme ne s’en empare, et il s'en emparera,
marquer du poinçon poétique certaines couvertures de romans populaires : Nick Carter,

Sûr Dubnotal, Buffalo-Bill, Texas- Jack et surtout Fantômas.

Signalons sans insister l'extraordinaire influence de cette imagerie sur le développement

du cinéma et arrêtons-nous à l’action qu'elle eût sur la vision moderne et, partant, sur les

mœurs.

Certes Fantémas (1) surgit parmi cette littérature comme un des monuments les plus
formidables de la poésie spontanée. Le texte ici est digne de l'illustration. Toute la période
qui précéda la guerre y est décrite avec une précision qui concourt précisément au phénomène lyrique. Intrigues internationales, vie des petites gens, aspect des capitales et particulièrement de Paris, mœurs mondaines telles qu’elles sont, c’est-à-dire telles que les imagine

le peuple, mœurs bourgeoises, mœurs policières et présence pour la première fois du mer-

veilleux propre au XX® siècle, utilisation naturelle des machines et des récentes inventions,
mystère des choses, des hommes et du destin.
Les

trente-deux

de

volumes

cette

épopée

moderne

possèdent

chacun

une

couverture

représentant l'une des scènes du roman. Chose étrange ce n'est pas toujours la scène la plus
marquante qui est utilisée mais c’est toujours la plus curieuse.
La couverture du premier volume représentant Fantômas lui-même, en chapeau haut
de forme, cape et masque, se dressant gigantesque et posant le pied sur Paris, prit une im-

portance énorme dans la mythologie et l’onirologie parisiennes. L'élégance du héros, le poi-

gnard sanglant qu'il tient à la main bouleversèrent des idées reçues et détruisirent l'idée
de l’escarpe miteux, lamentable et vêtu de haïllons qui avait lui-même remplacé un autre

gentleman

: Rocambole.

Les cauchemars dont une affiche de l’époque donne une idée très exacte (derrière une

porte, deux rentiers en chemise de nuit et bonnet

de coton,

bougeoir à la main, écoutent

deux perceurs de murailles s'acharner sur un invincible verrou de sûreté) devinrent la proie
du “ Roi de l'épouvante ”’. Il était beau, séduisant, élégant. on pouvait l'aimer et, s'il a été
un idéal romantique pour beaucoup de garçons, il est hors de doute qu'il fut un idéal roma377

Si Fantômas

était l'animateur

de toutes

ces révolutions, 1l était puissamment

secondé

dans son action psychique par les affiches qui, à propos de la publication d'un roman feuilleton

dans un journal (presque toujours le Matin ou le Petit Parisien) était collées sur les murs ;
qui ne se souvient de Balaoo (Il y a des pas au plafond) : de Cheri Bibi (Pas les mains ! Pas
les mains !); des Mystères de Passy (où le viaduc de Passy s’enfonçait sinistrement dans une

monde,

série à laquelle vint s'ajouter le célèbre ‘‘ Plus près de toi, 6 mon Dieu. ” qui illustra

le naufrage du Titanic.

|

Là on rejoignait l'univers si sensible de la chanson qui s’harmonisait étonnamment
avec cette atmosphère tragique et mystérieuse : “ Et voilà la journée terminée ”, La “ Valse
brune ”, ‘ Mariette ”’ (souvenir de l'affaire Steinheil) et l'époque se dressait ainsi sous
l'aspect extraordinaire de Fragson, assis à son piano A. Bord (quel enfant n’a pas cherché le
piano ‘“ à bord ‘’ des bateaux parisiens) un pied sur Paris, l’autre sur Londres.
De Fragson qui devait mourir si tragiquement, comme un personnage de Fantômas.
Et chaque mois paraissait un nouveau volume : un monde de religieuses s’affrontant

revolver au poing, dans un entrepont de bateau, en présence d’un cercueil vide, de rois

emprisonnés

dans les sirènes des fontaines de la Place de la Concorde,de mains coupées

sur le tapis de la roulette de Monte-Carlo, de fiacre conduit par un cocher mort, d'assassin
vidant dans la Seine le contenu macabre d'un carton à chapeau : une tête exsangue de femme
respirant des roses noires au parfum

empoisonné.

Tous les éléments de la magie et de la prophétie se trouvaient projetés dans l'imagination
universelle sans oublier l'humour représenté par ces fils du Père Ubu : les Pieds nickelés, et
la locution

courante

: Merci

pour

la langouste

!

Ainsi à l'insu des hommes, des forces magiques se heurtaient dans l'univers et le Sûr

Dubnotal lui-même malgré ses facultés extraordinaires de psychagogue (sic) était impuissant

à les asservir. Seul l’effroyable bain de sang de la guerre devait noyer dans ses vagues de
pourpre et de boue toutes ces divinités admirables.
Renaîtront-elles un jour par la grâce des rapports sentimentaux actuels à la naissance
desquels elles ont présidé?

Robert DESNOS.

Le crachat accompagne le souffle, qui ne peut sortir
de la bouche sans s'en imprégner. Or, le souffle est
l'âme, à tel point que certains peuples ont la notion

La salive est de l’âme déposée ; le crachat est de

Le crachat touche de très près aux manifestations

DÉBACLE.

— Les phénomènes

naturels sont un

vaste alphabet de symboles dans lequel nous puisons
pour forger nombre de nos expressions. Qui ne connaît
le coup de foudre,

le déjeuner de soleil, la tempête sous

un crâne et l'avalanche de compliments ?
Pour usées que soient la plupart de ces images, il en
est une portant qui demeure émouvante, à cause de

sa brutale et implacable concision, mot très exacte-

ment “ bâclé ” avec cette hâte même qui caractérise
les désastres, — je veux dire la débâcle.
Employée à propos de la guerre de 1870 dans l’œuvre

de Zola qui la porte comme titre, et popularisée surtout pour désigner les chutes monétaires et les krachs
financiers, cette expression est encore aujourd'hui
extrêmement forte, d'autant plus forte même qu'étant

données les circonstances
pour prophétique.

actuelles

elle peut passer

En effet, la vie aujourd’hui se trouve liée et gelée
dans l’épaisse glace industrielle qui voudrait nous
changer en cadavres. Les fleuves des relations vrai-

ment

humaines

sont

immobiles

et morts,

le froid

gagne, l'air se fige, et, de même que pendant cet hiver
1870-1871 qu'aiment à rappeler les plus affreux

382

vieillards, la Seine solidifiée tendit son dos, son échine
d'eau durcie, au passage des voitures, des passants
et des camions,

en artères

nos fleuves sentimentaux se changent

pleines

d'un

sang refroidi qui se caille,

boulevards pour les animalcules tenaces d'un état
de choses où rien n'a d'autre raison d'être qu’une
raison d'être économique, rapports sociaux mesquins
et sales comme des poux, plus difficile à supporter
par nos colonnes vertébrales que des chargements
entiers de voitures maraîchères ou que des omnibus
pleins à craquer d'hommes à figure nécessairement
ignoble. Prisonniers de ce froid comme les momies
le sont de leurs bandelettes raidies, dans des poses
grimaçantes de paralytiques honteux, nous ne bougeons pas, nous restons inertes, nous ne nous sentons
même pour ainsi dire plus morceaux de bois, et pourtant
nous n'espérons rien tant que la débâcle.
Si

le fleuve

dégelait,

c'en

serait

fait

de

ce

trafic

qui nous attache, de cette grotesque circulation de
minimes calculs qui nous courbent sous le joug et fait
de nous pire que des domestiques. Pour sortir de ce
débarras plein de poussière dans lequel nous moisissons, nous et nos défroques dédorées — aussi
rouillés que le vieux sabre d'un cuirassier de Reischoffen

—

il faudrait

que

les eaux

de

nos

cœurs,

de

nos muscles, de notre peau reprennent leur état naturel,

retrouvant en même temps dans son entier leur primitive violence, celle du temps des déluges, des cata-

clysmes

glaciaires

et des raz de marée,

pour

rompre

les quais, barrages séculaires, et se répandre à travers
tous les pays, que ce soient terres en friche, champs,
villes, hameaux,

sur leur passage
que

cette

tout.

—

noyant tout ce qui n’a rien d’humain

et finalement s’évaporant,

résurrection

se

transforme

sur

de sorte

l'heure

en

défaite et n'ait en somme pour ultime résultat, après
avoir d’abord brisé ce qui lui était hostile et étranger
puis s'être détruite elle-même en se changeant en
chimérique vapeur, que d'avoir anéanti absolument

*

Ce passage des Confessions d'un mangeur d'opium
suit immédiatement le récit que donne Thomas de
Quincey de la rencontre qu'il fit, dans une maison
quasi abandonnée où il avait loué un logement, d’une

pauvre enfant terrorisée par les fantômes,

souffrant

de la faim et du froid, et qui, la nuit, se serrait contre
lui pour se rassurer et se réchauffer ; puis l’histoire

émouvante de la petite prostituée

londonienne

Ann

avec laquelle Quincey, lors de ses plus sombres jours,
parcourait tristement Îles trottoirs d'Oxford-street,
et qui uné fois le sauva peut-être de la mort par
inanition en lui offrant, de sa misérable bourse, un

verre de porto épicé.

Les scènes les plus brillantes de Fox Follies, si attrayantes qu’elles soient, doivent céder le pas à deux
tableaux bien plus inattendus, dans lesquels se fait
jour cette magie de la rue, étincelante ou obscure
mais toujours écrin de velours merveilleux où luisent,
que l’on s’en doute ou non, les larmes grisantes d’une
jeune fille. Celle qui se lamente, jolie mais trop
modestement vêtue, devant la vitrine somptueuse d’un

magasin, jusqu'à ce que les figures de cire s’animent

et l'attirent en rêve à elles pour lui essayer les plus
belles parures, celle qui sanglote sous la neige, tandis
qu’une foule interlope de gens de toutes couleurs
s'agite par éclairs, avec des gestes d’une inexprimable

absurdité,— ces deux petites marchandes d’allumettes

de légende enfantine, ou orphelines de mélodrame,
et celles mêmes qui ne pleurent pas : les sirènes qui
au cours d’un ballet sous-marin descendent et remontent

lentement

le

long

d'énormes

algues,

telles

les

”,

tout

l'érotisme

de

sur

tandis

etc...

ENGLISH
IGOR

STRAWINSKY'S

1929.

SUPPLEMENT

CAPRICCIO

With no other musician has the power to create works entailed to
such an extent that of reforming public opinion, always at fault before
a musical evolution, too slowly followed by the terms “ classical ”,
“ modern ‘’ and many others. Whether he wished to do so or not —
and as a matter of fact he never did — Strawinsky, by his successive
works, drew up a kind of requisitory, such as no other composer had
to establish against a commonly accepted scale of values, against a
table of the aesthetic faults of a period, the support of our present day
weaknesses, the refuge of all our incapacities ; against the ideal of a
sham art, which tried to pass for great. The moment had never been
so ill chosen as when a few aesthetes proclaimed the reign of “ pure
music ”’, and this at a time when nobody was capable of strictly
judging a work according to its musical content, and not in accordance
with the whim of vague ideas or the artificial perplexity of short, sighted
technical views : for to the misapprehensions of art literature had
been added those of the professional critics. ‘They know nothing of
art except its beaten track, along which they have trudged, and the
examples duly held up by the different schools. They are never
struck by the original parts of a work ; on the contrary they are much
more apt to criticise them adversely…
No doubt the Capriccio can be counted among Strawinsky's fortu-

nate works, which imposed themselves on the public from the outset ;

at any rate the finale (allegro capriccioso), by its rhythm, by its atmosphere of joy, gained the support of those whom the two first movements,
more esoteric, more allusive, had only partially won over. “ Apollo ”
and “ The Fairy's Kiss ”, “ Mavra ” and the Sonata for the piano
which are the sources of the Capriccio, have not however been reinstated. Às was the case with the “ Sacre ” or with “ Noces ”, the
Capriccio would seem to have provided another argument against
works, which one misappreciates : but does not such an argument turn
against the taste of those who only appreciate the qualities of a work,
when they are reproduced in a subsequent one ? The general taste,
that is the great confusion, which the purest forms of originality have
to face.

The Capriccio is the Fairy’s Kiss without Tchaïkowski, and Mavra
after a few years’ reflection — and itis Strawinsky atthe piano.
This
explains the success of this work, no doubt incomparably masterful,
but in favour of which time had at first brought considerable pressure
to bear. Mastery of form, mastery of orchestration. Whether we
listen to that ever mobile orchestration, although always full, even in
its least sonorous parts, or to that effect of variety produced by the
repetition of one tonality in the finale, we think of what Schubert said
of Beethoven towards the close of the latter’s life : “ Art has already
become for him a science : he knows what he CAN DO, and his imagination obeys his inexhaustible power of lthought. ”. Since ** Appollo ”
Strawinsky has entered into that extremely mysterious period, which

TT

RSS

certain geniuses only reach, when they are old men, and others at about
forty five years of age. His possibilities have extended in a new
direction, just as, when we look through a lens, we see in the sky
stars, which had up till then been invisible. Henceforward Strawinsky will depend much more upon himself, upon his own power of
thought than upon external objects. He will not so much try to limit
his means, as to increase his efforts. He now knows that he”can get
much more out of himself and that the essential point is to find within
himself his own power of meditation.
Just as much for himself as
for the public, which listens to him, a work like the Capriccio appears
as the sign of the victory of the mind.
Accarding to the article of André SCHAËEFFNER,

pp. 345-347.

A PAINTING BY ANTOINE CARON
In his “ Dogme et rituel de la haute magie ”” (2 édition 1861) El.
phas Lévi tells a story, taken from the “ Démonomanie des sorciers ”
by Bodin, which is perhaps the most illustrative of the inordinate
horror of all this period, during which the exquisite charm of the group
of painters, known as “ l’école de Fontainebleau, ” is mingled with the
barbarities of the wars of religion and the tragic use of the legendary
poisoned gloves. Ït would not be surprising if this story were untrue.
Ît is however no less significant than many others and is as follows :
“ King Charles IX, afflicted with a disease, the cause of which no
doctor could discover nor explain its terrifying symptoms, was about

todie.

The queen mother, who ruled him absolutely and who had eve-

rything to lose under another reign ; the queen mother, who has been
suspected of being the author of this disease even against her own
interests, because one always supposed that this woman, capable of
everything, conceived hidden ruses to serve unknown interests ; the
queen mother began by consulting the astrologers on behalf of the
king and then had recourse to the most abominable of magical practices. As the king’s state of health grew worse every day and finally
became hopeless, it was decided to consult the oracle of “* The bloody
head ”, and this is how this infernal operation was carried out :
They took a beautiful and innocent child ; they had him secretely
prepared for Holy Communion by one of the chaplains of the palace ;

then, when the day or rather the night of the sacrifice arrived, a Jaco.

bin monk, an apostate addicted to the occult practices of black magic,
commenced at midnight, in the sick man's room and in the presence
only of Catherine de Médicis and of her faithful adherents, what was
then known as the devil's mass.
During this mass, celebrated before the image of the devil, having
at his feet a cross upside down, the sorcerer consecrated two hosts,
one black and one white. The white one was given to the child, who
was clothed in his christening garments, and whose headiwas cut off on

His head,
the altar steps immediately after he had taken communion.
severed with one blow, was placed, still throbbing, on the large black
host, which covered the bottom of the paten, and was then taken to a
table, on which were burning mysterious lamps. Theïexorcism then
began and the devil was called upon to pronounce an oracle and to
reply by the mouth of this head to a secret question, which the king
did not dare to ask aloud and which he had not confided to anybody.
Then a feeble voice, a strange voice, which no longer had anything

human about it, proceeded from this small martyr's head.

“ Ï am

haunted by the ghost of Coligny and that he imagined he saw before

him the head of the illustrious admiral : the cause however of the dying

man's agitation was not remorse but terror without any hope and an
anticipation of hell. ”
This scene took place at the château de Vincennes in 1574, that is
eight years after Caron painted on silk the “* Massacres d’une pros-

It is curious to note that,

beside some dull paintings attributed to Caron, there are some illustrations for an edition of Ovid's Metamorphoses ** and a considerable
portion of the illustrations to the translation of “ Images ou Tableaux

de platte peinture, des deux Philostrate ”, by the illustrious hermetist

Blaise de Vigenère, executed (according to Nagler ) from his drawings.
It is moreover certain that Antoine Caron took an extraordimary pleasure in painting this picture. We only have to examine the details
— chiefly those in the centre of the picture — to be convinced that the
artist must have taken a very keen and special delight (of a lewd or

masochistic nature) in portraying these glaring horrors.

Like à child

who tortures domestic animals, beheads flies, bites his nails till they

bleed or plays a game that frightens him, Antoine Caron, six years
before Saint Barthélémy, represents in his paintings old men being

GASTON-LOUIS ROUX]
In°the midst of men

rise up intermittently, but very regularly,

reat personages, unforeseen, odd, tragic, the necessity of such beings
either reassuring us or terrifying us. ‘They are, as it were. the fireballoons of thought, the gold-beater's skins, the paste-board boxes
for carnivals and private parties, they are also “ the big, soft heads ”,
Ubu, Don Quixote, Eiffel, the powerless harbinger of a terrible statue.
For the last fifty years artists have been carried away by their brushes

The wands of these sorcerers, which! are undisciplined and vibrating,

peevishly bring toËlife again our fighting nature. Ï envy the artists,
who are specially chosen by those redoubtable guests, by those living

night-mares. Gaston-Louis Roux is one of these privileged artists.
It is no doubt difficult to say to what suggestions he responds when

he presents us with a were-wolf with a duck's head, that “ Tragedian ”

fixed like à prisnr. Certainly he would provide us with the key of the
enigma, but a key forged specially for the purpose, to serve as a justi-

fication, in which he would not believe himself,

However the secret

escapes everybody and more especially the painter himself, who,
having surprised us, is surprised at our surprise
and is finally caught
by the universal surprise.
|
The mechanism of painting has again begun to _operate. “One of
his last productions “ L'Arracheur de Dents ” (The toothdrawer)
must be considered, both from the standpoint of Roux’ evolution
and from that of the general signification of painting, as an event of
paramount importance, ‘To a complete tradition of vegetables, entrails,
craters and leprosy, to pharmacy, to the insane immobility of germs
and. impressions, Roux opposes monstrous automatons with their
invisible machinery.

. For too long a time we’were followed by heroic companions, by

gentlemen and Jadies, who pass through various epochs, making gestures, which we are surprised to find ourselves imitating, adopting
attitudes, which we copy. Ï, for my part, do not conceal the fact that
“ L'Arracheur de Dents ” (The toothdrawer) gives me the tone.

Firstly in the form of a kibney or haricot bean the monocular face of

the dentist, in which shines a second eye, the extracted tooth on the
end; of a pair of pincers, enhanced by the parallelopined of his hand,
which a green arm, bent like the taper of the internal chuckle, firmlv
fixes to the cmoplate, still vibrating frem the effort and the lady's
cry. ‘Then there is the lady, whose wavy hair sends forth the same
cry, as is suggested by her open “mouthk, a shriek, whichwithout effort
assumes the form of a necklace in yellow gold and dizzily, without
heeding the confusion between the arm of the chair and her own arm,
reaches a small contracted hand, around which is rolled, like a violin
stéing, : an Angelico blue tie. And lastly all those teeth, which, ladies,
give you a fine figure and pretty legs against a back-ground consisting of a mechanical grass-mower and on a chrome steel pedestal.
The whole composition produces a marvellous effect thanks to the
skilful use of perspective and colour, so much so that it seems as 1f
the dentist were going to walk out of the picture and that the lady were
going to fall backwards.
Gaston-Louis Roux, great portrayer of movement.

THE MARQUIS DE SADE’S HANDWRITING
We were surprised to learn from Freud himself that the Psychoanalysts had not yet had recourse to a method, which would open up
for them such vast horizons and enable them to found their theories
on a scientific basis.
During the course of his life a man is sometimes in a state of anguish
owing to the idea of death or to that of some threatening danger. Such
a state is revealed by his handwriting and more especially by distorted
letters. We reproduce here an envelope we received a few months

ago.

The lady who wrote the letter, informed

tumour and that an operation was

to die shortly.

impossible.

us that she had a

She

was expecting

The lines reproduced, back handwriting with many distorted
letters, are from a young. man, an exhibitionist, who was awaiting
in prison the doom kept in store for him by his judges.
Distorted letters also appear in the last missive written by those
condemned to death.
Graphologists also study the perversions of the sexual instinct as
well as the disorders which may result from the intraversion of this

instinct.

În this article we propose to deal only with the perversions

of the sexua ‘instinct.

We feel we cannot do better than to choose as the subject of our

study the Marquis de Sade, who was a sodomite, a masochist, who
was lewd and who spent the greater part of his life in prison as a result
of his debaucheries.

The portrait we have drawn of the Marquis de Sade differs from
that of public opinion, which represents him as a man completely
devoid of talent and monstrously obscene.
The Marquis de Sade gave himself up to debauchery because he

chose not to resist his passions.

He says so himself in the dialogue

between a priest and a dying man :
“ 1 only repent the fact that Î did not recognise her almighty power
(that of nature) and Honly feel remorse on account of the poor use I
made of the faculties (according to you criminal, but according to me
perfectly simple), which she gave me, so that Î could serve her. ”

LE JEU LUGUBRE.
Le “ Jeu Lugubre ” (the lugubrious game) by Salvador Dali
(c. f. Documents N° 4, pp. 217 et 229), which is now in the collection of the Vicomte de Noailles, is the subject of this article.
Dal's picture is remarkable on account of its depraved character,
of the expression of irreconciliable feelings. When faced with the
monstreus groups and tragi-comic nighimares ot Dali one immediately thinks of the digressions of the Marquis de Sade.

THE DOORS

to the article of Georges BATAILLE,

OF SAN-ZENO

pp.

AT VERONA

IMAGERY

The essential characteristic of the artist is to be tugged along by
some fashion or other. As he is incapable himself of discovering any
treasures, he is prepared to admire what others like, privided that time
or market value confers upon objects, frequentiy admirable, a pseudo
consecration.
He who a few dozen years ago despised the charming
Epinal pictures, today collects them, for the popular manifestations
of art are the chief victims of these sudden manias.
N
Although despised today, future generations will collect the illustrated supplements to the “ Petit Journal ” and ,, Petit Parisien ”,
which provide so expressive a commentary on topical events and
history.

Ï should like today, beforelit becomes the rage, — and it certainlv

will — to explain the poetry contained in the illustrated bindings to
certain popular novels : “ Nick Carter, ” “ Sâr Dubnotal, ” “* Buffalo

Bill, ” “ Texas Jack, ” and especially “ Fantômas.”

I should just like to allude briefly to the extraordinary influence of
this form of imagery on the development of the cinema and to' consider
‘fairly fully ïts l'action upon our present ideas and consequently upon

our morals.

Certainly “ Fantômas *’ arises out of this kind of literature like
one of the most formidable examples of spontaneous poetry. The
entire pre-war period is described therein with a precision, which
helps to bring out the lyrical aspect of the work.
Each of the bindings of the thirty two volumes of this modern
epopee represent one of the scenes of the novel. Strangely enough
it is not always the most significant scene, which is portrayed, but it

is always the most curious,

L

un

The binding of the first volume, representing Fantômas himself,
wearing a top hat, cape and mask and looming up as a gigantic figure
with his foot on Paris, came to be an enormously important factor
in Parisian mythology and onirology. The hero's elegant appearance
and the bloody dagger he holds in his hand upset the generally accepted
ideas and put an end to the notion of a lamentable, moth-eaten assassin,
clothed in rags, who had in turn replaced another gentleman : Rocam-

bole.

Fantômas’ influenceË was considerably enhanced by the posters,
which, whenever a serial story appears in one of the newspapers (almost
always “* Le Matin ” or “ Le Petit Parisien ”’), are stuck on the walls.
One was wafted into the enchanting realm of song, so astonishingly
‘
in keeping with this tragic and mysterious atmosphere.
the
All the elements of magic and prophesy were projected into
universal imagination.
Thus, unknown to men, magic forces were clashing against each

other in the universe and Sâr Dubnotal himself, in spite of his powers of

THE ” ADVANCED ” CINEMA
- Owing to an excessive regard for art a whole group of producers,
actors and spectators have been led to evolve a form of entertainment
known as the “ advanced *’ cinema, which is remarkable for the fac
that its productions are very rapidly out of date, that they portray no
human emotions and that they constitute a danger to the cinema,
taken as.a whole.

{wish to make myself clear.

When René Clair and Picabia produced

“ Entr'acte ”, Man Ray “ L'étoile de Mer” and Buñuel his admirable
“ Chien andalou ”, there was no question of creating a work of art or
new aesthetic principles, but of representing deep and original psycho
logical movements, which consequently required a new form of expres-

sion.

The films ! wish to criticise are those of the inhuman kind, such as

“* 24 heures en 30 minutes *” and “ Montreur d’ombres ” ete.

The employment of technical processes, which the action does not
render necessary, conventional effects, the claim to express the arbitrary and complicated movements of the soul, such are the chief
characteristics of this cinema, which I should not hesitate to call the
“ after-thought ” cinema.

And the fact of thus uniting in a communion of ideas the eminent

critic of “ l'Humanité ” and the penetrating Protestant reviewer
M. Jean Prévost of “ La Nouvelle Revue Française ” is not the least

funny point in the confusion.

|

Às a matter of fact “ advanced *”’ cinema, literature or drama is a
fiction. Anyone who pretends to be one of these timid revolutionists

pursues a policy of “ the cowl makes the friar. ”

..

Although the “ advanced ”” cinema discovered Charlie Chaplin four

or five years after the man in the street did, it claims him for its own.
Charlie Chaplin exists and that is all there is to it”

Ï do not agree. I have liked and admired Charlie Chaplin for
twelve years, but Î confess that Stroheim moves me in a more direct
manner, in a way which 1s better suited to my temperament.

And it is precisely because Stroheim has the pluck to show us love
as itis, that he is the most revolutionary and the most human of
present day managers.
The only revolutionary factor is frankness. ‘The characteristics of
‘all reactions are lying and insincerity. Anditis thanks to this frankness
that we are now able to place on the same plane the really revolutionary
films, such as “ The Potemkin ”, “ The Gold Rusch ”, “ La Symphonie Nuptiale ”, and “ Le Chien andalou ”, whereas, owing to their
obscurity, we can hardly distinguish between “ The Fall of the House
of Usher ”, revealing Epstein’s lack of imagination or rather the paralysis of his imagination, “ L'inhumaine “ and “ Panam n'est pas

Paris ”.

Ï crave permission not to write down the forcible and conclusive
expression, which would adequately define this form of art.
In order to appreciate these “ advanced ” people we merely need to
observe what was their attitude, when the sound films made their
. appearance.
Nothing but a cry of horror proceeded from the mouths of these

delicately minded gentlemen.

They convicted without appeal this invention, just as, at the beginning of the century, certain artists had convicted the cinema as a
whole. They used the same arguments. They took advantage of the
mediocrity of the productions of the time to condemn those of the
future.
According to the article of Robert DESNOS, pb. 385-387.
